reviewText: It certainly looked promising: Broadway's musical hit of 1953 with tunes robbed from (er, inspired by) late 19th-Century Russian composer Alexander Borodin, set in ancient Baghdad, Mesopotamia, with a great cast and MGM's top director of musical films, Vincente Minnelli (MEET ME IN SAINT LOUIS, AN AMERICAN IN PARIS) at the helm.But it just doesn't work.  KISMET (1955) is not an absolute stinker but a real disappointment; I'd give it two-and-a-half stars if I could.  Howard Keel, taking over Alfred Drake's Broadway role, and Dolores Gray as his temptress and would-be mistress, were wonderful.  Perfectly over-the-top on such delightful rhythms as the song "Radlakum":  YOU are DRIving me OUT of my MESopoTAMian MINNND!  But Vic Damone and Ann Blythe as the second leads were flat, uninspired and appeared completely out of their element.It was said that director Minnelli had the flu while KISMET was filming, so perhaps that furnishes the excuse.  How else could such a play be so clumsily translated from B'way to MGM -- in spite of a "quality picture" budget and schedule?  Most of the "hot-cha" numbers (in a film with lots of "hot-chas") involve specialty dancers who look flat and stagy, the widescreen camera poised at what would be center stage in a real theater -- resulting in static, perfunctory numbers.  This contrasts poorly with the "Minnellian camera," the fluidity of "Dancing in the Dark" in THE BAND WAGON (1953) or "The Night They Invented Champagne" in GIGI (1958).  And probably it was funnier on stage to have the Wazir's guards speak with thick Brooklyn accents.Oh, there is some subsidiary fun, including Sebastian Cabot (of TV's "FAMILY AFFAIR") but mostly I remember the lusty and lustful singing by Keel, Dolores Gray, and the two in duet.  Otherwise, the novice viewer can be forgiven for getting bored with this flat confection long before it has played out.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Must admit I was a trifle disappointed in "Kismet."  Remembered fondly seeing Zero Mostel as the wazir in a stage version in the 50's.  Admittedly he is a tough act to follow.  The costumes and production design are colorful and music is lovely certainly.  Howard Keel and Ann Blyth are perfect for their roles, and Dolores Gray offers the only real juice in the piece.  She is worth the price of admission.  Somehow the whole thing though seems somewhat lifeless.  Not one of the great MGM musicals of the 50's.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, this is an excellent video transfer, but a poor audio one. That's a major problem with a musical. It's coded as Dolby digital 5.1, but it sounds more like a mediocre grade of mono, which is a shame because this seems to be the only DVD release of the film available. Maybe someday it will be released with an audio track that does justice to the film, and if so I might have to buy it again.The film is a lavish technicolor extravaganza, gaudy, melodramatic, not poorly acted but there's not much to be done with this material, which draws heavily on the comic opera tradition. It's a fun film, and much of the pleasure comes from the almost surreal juxtaposition of technicolor lycra filmed in the sexually repressed 50's (very little skin shown in this film) with the elegant 19th century music of Alexander Borodin. It's a perfect piece of camp, and memorable for it.
summary: Mediocre transfer of a fine film
Title: N/A

reviewText: The film version of the stafe musical "Kismet" is not one of MGM's finest, despite coming from the studio's fabled Arthur Freed unit. It simply doesn't have the acting talent (Vic Damone is particularly underwhelming as the Caliph) or the production value of "Singing in the Rain" or "Gigi." Nonetheless, it is still colorful, splashy, and a great deal of fun. Howard Keel is in particularly fine voice and really fills out his robes. Anne Blyth (better known as the evil Veda from "Mildred Pierce,") is delightful as Marsinah and also has a beautiful voice. And Dolores Gray as Lalume steals every scene. It is a pity she didn't do more movies.
summary: One of the Best B Musicals
Title: N/A

reviewText: A friend of ours had been telling me how wonderful this movie was but I could never find a copy locally.  He finally bought this DVD and we all loved it!  It has fabulous costumes, a clever story, good music and, of course, Howard Keel!  What's not to love?  The extras were fun also.  This one is all it's billed to be!

reviewText: This movie is one of my all time favourite Howard Keel movies.  I remember watching it as a child with my mother.
